questions.question: What is the most important pathophysiological factor implicated in GERD?
Which of the following foods will you recommend to a patient to reduce symptoms of GERD?
questions.explanation: Protein increases the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure, thereby allowing the closure ofthe sphincter and reducing reflux.Other options:Option A: Chocolate and coffee both contain methylxanthine, which causes muscles to relax andlowers the LES pressure. In addition, coffee can stimulate gastric secretions, which can promotereflux.Option C: Fatty foods have been found to delay gastric emptying and decrease the LES pressure,thereby prolonging the esophageal exposure time to the stomach acid and the volume available forreflux.Option D: Alcohol, mint, citrus, tomatoes, and/or carbonated beverages may cause furtherirritation to the damaged esophageal mucosa but have not been found to cause reflux themselves.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a feeling of fullness and sensation of a lump in thethroat for the past 3 weeks. He has no other complaints like weight loss or dysphagia. Rigidendoscopy showed no growth or foreign body in the throat. Which of the following statementsis false regarding this condition?

options.A: Lump in the throat only felt during swallowing
options.C: Does not interfere with eating or drinking

questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of globus hystericus. It is a feeling of fullness orlump in the throat that is felt always and not only when swallowing.Globus hystericus or globus pharyngeus is a persistent abnormal sensation in the throat in theabsence of any observable pathology. The exact cause of globus sensation is uncertain. Thesensation is often relieved by the act of swallowing and it does not interfere with eating anddrinking.Examination and investigations may be carried out to exclude any other underlying problem. It isoften attributable to GERD. Reassurance that there is no serious underlying problem may be allthat is needed in terms of treatment.

questions.question: A 67-year-old man presented to the physician with complaints of heartburn and a sour tastein the mouth for the past 1 year. He was prescribed proton pump inhibitors, but the394symptoms did not improve. What is the immediate next step in the management of thispatient?
questions.explanation: This is a case of dyspepsia not responding to PPIs. So the best management for this patient isendoscopy.In case of an unexplained dyspepsia••• If the patient is >60 years - Endoscopy is the investigation of choice•If the patient is <60 years - A test for H.pylori infection is done (stool antigen and ureasebreath test) and eradication treatment is given. Endoscopy is done only if any one of the alarmingsigns are present.Alarming signs401•Odynophagia or dysphagia• Unexplained weight loss• Massive GI bleeding⚫ Recurrent vomiting••Jaundice• Palpable mass or adenopathy•Family history of GI malignancy

questions.question: A 48-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain that is relievedby loud belching. On examination, the patient had pallor. Chest radiography showed anintrathoracic gas bubble. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with X-ray findings showing a retrocardiac gas bubble are consistentwith the diagnosis of a hiatus hernia. A CT scan with oral contrast is the best method ofdiagnosis. It highlights the gastric anatomy but also helps to identify other structures involved inthe hiatal hernia.Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into thethoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.Types of hiatus hernia:Type 1- sliding herniaGastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intraabdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. Thetreatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication.Type 2- rolling hiatus hernia:Gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into thethoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rollinghiatus hernia.Clinical features:• Chest pain or fullness relieved on belching..⚫ Dysphagia.• Longitudinal ulcers (Cameron's ulcer) that bleed lead to anemia.Surgical reduction of hernia and tightening of diaphragmatic crura is the best treatment modalityeven in asymptomatic patients to avoid life-threatening complications like volvulus.Type 3- mixed hiatus hernia:A combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia. Treatment is the same as rolling hiatus hernia.Type 4 hiatus hernia:Other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Eg: Colon.402Types of Hiatal HerniaGastroesophagealjunctionType 1Sliding herniaNormalRType 3Mixed typeOMARROWType 2Rolling herniaType 4Paraesophageal herniaNote: This is a controversial question as some books give barium swallow as the investigation ofchoice for hiatal hernia. But Bailey's 28th edition clearly mentions that a CT scan with oralcontrast is the answer.The image below shows a retrocardiac gas bubble on an X-ray that is consistent with hiatushernia.

questions.question: What is the most common complication of Nissen's fundoplication?
questions.explanation: The most common complication of Nissen's fundoplication is gas-bloat syndrome.Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lowerend of the esophagus.403EsophagusDiaphragmNissen's fundoplicationFundusMARROWFundus wrapped aroundthe esophagusWrap secured with sutures toanchor lower esophagusbelow diaphragmMARROWAfter this procedure, most patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the esophagus.This causes increased gas in the stomach resulting in bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort,and flatulence. This is known as gas bloat syndrome and occurs more commonly with Nissen totalfundoplication.Pneumothorax is the most common complication that occurs intraoperatively.

questions.question: The fundus is wrapped (270 degrees) around the posterior aspect of the esophagus in whichof the following corrective procedures for GERD?
questions.explanation: Partial posterior fundoplication between 180 to 270 degrees is called Toupet fundoplication.It is used in the surgical management of GERD. Partial anterior fundoplication is Dor'sfundoplication and total fundoplication is Nissen's fundoplication.Types of fundoplicationNissens fundoplication (360°)Toupet fundoplication (180°-270° posterior)Dor fundoplication (180°-200° anterior)OMARROW404

questions.question: What is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus?
questions.explanation: Leiomyomas are the most common benign tumors of the esophagus.Leiomyomas are benign tumors that arise from the muscularis propria. They are found in the midto distal esophagus.They are more common in males and small, asymptomatic lesions are observed, whilesymptomatic lesions are enucleated.T

questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing squamous cell carcinoma of theesophagus?
questions.explanation: Barrett's esophagus is a risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the lower end of the esophagus, not forsquamous cell carcinoma.Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of esophageal carcinoma.Risk factors for SCC:• Tobacco• Alcohol• HPV• Plummer-Vinson syndrome• Achalasia• Tylosis•Caustic ingestionRisk factors for adenocarcinoma:• Barrett's esophagusGERD405• Smoking•Obesity

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about Barrett's esophagus?

options.A: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
options.B: Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
options.C: Alician blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
options.D: It is a reversible cell adaptation

questions.explanation: Mucus-secreting goblet cells (not foveolar cells) are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus, as thereis intestinal metaplasia of the esophagus. Foveolar cells are the mucus-secreting cells in thestomach.Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and itis estimated to occur in about 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Symptoms includeheartburn, regurgitation and sometimes dysphagia. Obese white men over the age of 60years represent the highest-risk group.Intestinal metaplasia in the esophagus occurs due to chronic irritation of the esophagus in GERD(option A) since intestinal epithelium is better suited to handling gastric acid exposure. Hence,mucus-secreting goblet cells are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus. Since all metaplasia arereversible, Barrett's esophagus is also reversible (option D). Only 0.2 to 1% of Barrett's esophagusleads to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma.Barrett's EsophagusGoblet cells(intestinal metaplasia)Alician blue is used in the staining of the biopsy specimen, as it stains the goblet cells (option C).Mucicarmine is the specific stain.Seattle protocol is used for the management of Barrett's esophagus.406Management of Barrett's Esophagus(Seattle Protocol)Seattle protocolBarrett's onlyDysplasiaMetaplasiaAblation ofabnormalmucosa- RFA- APCContinue2 yearly protocolCancerSurgery(esophagectomy)Low grade dysplasiaHigh grade dysplasia6 month protocolRFA3 month protocolRadiofrequency ablationAPCArgon photocoagulationOMARROW

questions.question: Investigation of choice for cardia metaplasia in Barrett's esophagus is
questions.explanation: The investigation of choice for Barrett's esophagus showing cardia metaplasia is endoscopy withmethylene blue.Barrett's esophagus is a metaplastic change (squamous to columnar change) in the lower end ofthe esophagus as a result of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease.Barrett's esophagus can be-• Classical Barrett's esophagus -> 3cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus.•Short segment Barrett's esophagus - < 3cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus.• Cardia metaplasia - microscopic Barrett's in the GE junction. In cardia metaplasia due to lack ofmacroscopic changes, an endoscopic biopsy is difficult. So chromoendoscopy is the idealinvestigation. Here mucosa is first stained by methylene blue to highlight abnormal mucosa.Investigation of choice: endoscopic biopsyManagement: Seattle protocol is ideally followed to detect early dysplastic changes in Barrett'sesophagus. Here a 4 quadrant biopsy specimen is taken 1-2 cm apart throughout the area ofintestinal metaplasia.• No signs of dysplasia - continue 2 yearly surveillance.••Low-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 6 monthly surveillance.High-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 3 monthly surveillance.APC Argon photo coagulation-RFA Radiofrequency ablation-EMR Endoscopic mucosal resectionLugol's iodine is used for squamous cell carcinoma.407Management of Barrett's Esophagus(Seattle Protocol)Seattle protocolBarrett's onlyDysplasiaMetaplasiaContinue2 yearly protocolCancerAblation ofabnormalmucosa- RFASurgery(esophagectomy)- APCLow grade dysplasiaHigh grade dysplasia6 month protocol3 month protocolRFAAPCRadiofrequency ablationArgon photocoagulationMARROW

questions.question: Endoscopic biopsy of a patient with GERD revealed high-grade dysplasia of esophagealmucosa proximal to the GE junction. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

options.A: Radiofrequency ablation and 6 monthly follow up
options.B: No intervention now and follow up every 2 years
options.C: Argon photocoagulation and 3 monthly follow up

questions.explanation: Ablation of abnormal mucosa and 3 monthly endoscopic protocol is the appropriate managementin cases of high-grade dysplasia of esophageal mucosa due to GERD.Management of Barrett's esophagus(American College ofGastroenterology guidelines)NodysplasiaRepeatEGD every3-5 yearsFlat columnar mucosaSystematic cold biopsyConfirm dysplasia by2 different pathologistsIndefinite fordysplasiaRepeat EGD withmaximal acidsuppressionDefinitedysplasiaFollow LGDor HGDflowchartBEHGDLGDEGDLGDHGD or TiaAdenocarcinomaEGD every6 monthsTherapeuticintervention2 consecutivenon-dysplastic BEEndoscopiceradicationtherapyFollowno-dysplasiaflowchartBarrett's esophagusHigh-grade dysplasiaLow-grade dysplasiaEsophagogastroduodenoscopyOMARROW

questions.question: An 80-year-old male patient was recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.The tumor is present in the distal esophagus, within 1 to 5 cm above the gastroesophagealjunction. According to the Siewert classification, which type does this tumor belong to?
questions.explanation: Siewert type I lesions include tumors of the distal esophagus with the center located within 1 - 5cm above the anatomic esophagogastric junction.408Siewert classification ofgastroesophageal junction tumorsType I5 cm1 cmType II-2 cmType III-5 cmMARROWDistalesophagusTrue cardiaZ-line (GEJ)Sub cardia

questions.question: An elderly male presented with significant weight loss and an inability to swallow food. Abarium swallow was done and showed the following. Which of the following statements isfalse regarding this condition?397

options.A: Dysphagia is the most common symptom
options.B: Tia tumor is restricted to sub mucosa.Barium swallow shows rat tail appearanced) Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is used to confirm diagnosisQuestion 15:What is the blood supply of the conduit in gastric pull up done during esophagectomy?a) Right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteriesb) Right gastric and left gastroepiploic arteries
options.C: Left gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries
options.D: Left gastric and left gastroepiploic arteries

questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario with rat-tail appearance on barium swallow is suggestive of esophagealcarcinoma. Tia tumor is restricted to the muscularis mucosa.Esophageal carcinoma is more commonly seen in men. Tobacco use and alcohol are strong riskfactors. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are the two mostcommon types.Clinical features include:•Dysphagia (most common)•Regurgitation• Vomiting•Odynophagia• Weight lossIn the advanced stage, there can be hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy,horner's syndrome, chronic spinal pain, and diaphragmatic paralysis.Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Other Investigationsinclude barium swallow which shows a rat-tail appearance due to irregular narrowing orulceration. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopicultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumor invasion and lymph nodemetastasis.TNM staging:Primary Tumor (T)TXTumor cannot be assessed409Primary Tumor (T)ToTisT1T2T3T4aT4bRegional Lymph Nodes(N)NXNoN1N2N3Distant Metastasis (M)MoNo evidence of tumorHigh-grade dysplasiaTumor invades the muscularis mucosa (Tia) or submucosa(T1b)Tumor invades into but not beyond the muscularis propriaTumor invades the adventitiaTumor invades adjacent structures that are usually resectable(diaphragm and pericardium)Tumor invades unresectablestructuresRegional lymph nodes cannotbe assessedNo regional lymph node metastasisMetastasis in 1-2 regional lymph nodesMetastasis in 3-6 regional lymph nodesMetastasis in ° 7 regional lymph nodesNo distant metastasisM1Distant metastasis

questions.question: A 50-year-old man is diagnosed with esophageal carcinoma. Radiological investigations showa 2 cm tumor in the middle part of the esophagus. The tumor extends up to the submucosawith the involvement of mediastinal lymph nodes, there is no distant metastasis. What is thebest treatment modality in his case?
questions.explanation: Chemoradiation followed by esophagectomy is the best treatment modality for tumors extendingto the submucosa (Tib) with regional lymph node involvement (N1).EMR (endoscopic mucosal resection) is done for small tumors confined to the mucosa, with nolymph node involvement. (T1aNo)Esophagectomy ± chemoradiation is done when the tumor extends into the submucosa, with nolymph node involvement.411Chemoradiation followed by esophagectomy is done for tumors extending into the submucosa orbeyond with lymph node enlargementChemoradiation therapy alone is done as a palliative measure in case of advanced esophagealcarcinoma or in those patients unfit for surgery.Esophageal stent placement is done in patients with advanced cancer and severe dysphagia that isnot resolved by chemoradiation therapy. SEMS (self-expanding metallic stent) is the treatment ofchoice in malignant tracheoesophageal fistula.

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman presented with a history of dysphagia and weight loss for the past 1year. Endoscopic ultrasonography done showed a tumor of size 4 cm in the mid esophagusabove the aortic arch. Which of the following is the best approach?
questions.explanation: The best surgical approach for a mid-esophageal carcinoma above the aortic arch is Mckeown'sesophagectomy.Approaches of esophagectomy:1. Mckeown's approach•• Done for upper 1/3rd and mid 1/3rd tumors (above aortic arch)• Anastomosis site is in the neck•Three incisions were made (abdominal, thoracic, and left neck)2. Transhiatal approach (Orringer's approach)• Done for tumor of lower 1/3rd and mid 1/3rd of the esophagus•• Anastomosis site is in the neck3. Ivor Lewis approach•• Done for mid 1/3rd(below aortic arch) and lower 1/3rd esophagus tumors• Anastomosis site is in the thorax• The most common complication is atelectasis•The most common cause of mortality is due to an anastomotic leak leading to mediastinitis.In esophagectomy, a proximal margin of 10cm and a distal margin of 5cm is taken.

questions.question: An male patient with stage IV esophageal carcinoma is taken up for esophageal stentinsertion as a palliative measure. Which of the following is the most common complication ofthis procedure?
questions.explanation: The most common complication of placing a stent in the esophagus is the migration of the stent.Palliative treatment in advanced stages of esophageal carcinoma includes esophageal stentplacement, enteral nutrition support, or the use of chemotherapy and radiation.Complications of esophageal stent placement:• Migration of stent (most common)•⚫ Odynophagia• Tumour ingrowth and overgrowth412⚫ Chest pain•• Severe refluxge19189. Buth31/2005PAZAvskelanta

questions.question: AIMS65 score is used to predict mortality rate in patients with which of the following?
questions.explanation: AIMS65 score is a simple risk score that predicts the mortality rate in patients with upper GIhaemorrhage.AIMS65 scoreVariableAlbumin <3 g/dlINR >1.5AlteredMental statusSystolic BP<90mmHgAge>65yearsScore>2consideredhigh riskScore11111413
